citations.narrative:
Members of the public were allowed to interact with a ring-tailed lemur that runs around in the encounter arena. During
this encounter, the lemur was allowed to climb on the shoulder of the adult patron. In addition, a child was seen holding
the lemur’s leash while supervised by the animal handler. Photograph and video footage were provided to USDA officials
displaying this particular encounter. When discussing these concerns with the facility, the licensee stated they were under
the impression that direct control of the animal was provided by the facility by controlling the environment in which the
encounter took place, and using staff that were highly trained and knowledgeable of the individual lemurs’ behaviors and
body language. When a picture of the encounter was shown to the licensee during the inspection, they confirmed that the
patrons were members of the public, and not staff members.
Interactions involving hands-on contact with the public and wild and potentially dangerous animals, if not under direct
control of an experienced handler, risks the wellbeing and safety of both the animals and public due to the unpredictability
of the interactions. The facility must ensure that dangerous animals are under the direct control and supervision of a
knowledgeable and experienced animal handler. The facility shall ensure animals are directly controlled during public
exhibition.
Correct by June 18, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
